I think with rules JUnit could be a very thin execution framework that can
=
have aspects of running and reporting enhanced with interceptors. With JUni=
t
being the defacto standard in all IDE's that would be a solid base for
ex=
tenders to add their own flavors of testing.

For some reason Daniel nailed=
 pretty much my whole list and I agree with all
of it. I don't share Daniel=
's talent for terseness so I do what I do best:
Wordspray, with some luck i=
t sheds some more light in some dark corner:

One thing that I can add to D=
aniel's list is:
* filtering. If you had global rules you could allow exten=
ders to filter the
testrun based on whatever is available, like annotations=
. It seems to me
like ignore and the recent categories could be implemented=
 this way.
I know that an @ignore(until=3D<time>) has been suggested before=
, that kind of
support could easily be implemented with global rules. I hav=
e personally
wanted a @pending annotation, with global rules I could just g=
o ahead and
add that one (Ignore until it works, and fail passing tests mar=
ked with
@pending. These kind of enhancements are hard to predict and make =
a "one
solution to satisfy all" but would be easy to do with global rules a=
nd JUnit
could remain a thin (but extendable) intersection.


* Another exa=
mple of reporting would be one that I implemented with a runner
before. To =
mark the start and end of a test and dump log-statements if the
test fails.=
 That allows tests to be quiet but the statements that were
logged during t=
he testrun would be available upon failure. Custom reporting
and resource h=
ousekeeping like this would be the showcase feature for global
rules I thin=
k.


Harder to do (I think) but still useful:

* Global rules could also al=
low some creative configurations of tests:
Lets say that you want to use a =
special runner for all tests under a certain
package annotated with a certa=
in annotation. If there were a interception
point where the runner is creat=
ed that would be possible too.

* Customization according to taste: Let's s=
ay that I prefer @Given instead
of @Before, @Spec instead of @Test and so o=
n. With a global rule I could
replace the default runner with a custom one =
(given an interception point
when the runner is created).

In short, I thin=
k global rules would be like XMas for JUnit-extenders :)
